title: Arizona Community Colleges' Student Organizations (Pima Community College)

communications.subject: Arizona Public Records Law Request: Arizona Community Colleges' Student Organizations (Pima Community College)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Arizona Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. A copy of any policy concerning recognition or registration of student organizations at your institution or at any institution within your district.

2. A copy of any list of active or recognized student organizations at your institution or at any institution within your district.

3. A copy of any list of contact information for active or recognized student organizations at your institution or at any institution within your district.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

communications.subject: Re: Arizona Public Records Law Request: Arizona Community Colleges' Student Organizations (Pima Community College)
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Steinbaugh -

I have attached two documents responsive to your record request:
1. PCC Student Life 2024-2025 List - a list of current and inactive student
organizations at Pima Community College
2. PCC Club Policies - a list of links to policies and web sites related to
student organizations Pima Community College

In your request you asked for this information for our community college
district "or at any institution within your district."  We are not
responsible for any other institutions within our district, other than our
own community college.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Libby Howell

communications.subject: ICE FOIA Request 2022-ICFO-14106
communications.communication:
May 04, 2022 Andrew Free MuckRock News DEPT MR 122335, 411A Highland Ave Somerville, Massachusetts 02144-2516 RE:     ICE FOIA Case Number 2022-ICFO-14106  Dear  Free: This acknowledges receipt of your December 22, 2021, Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), for all records pertaining to FOIA request 2021-ICFO-32710. This request includes, but is not limited to search taskings, processing notes, and communication regarding the agency’s processing and response..  Your request was received in this office on May 04, 2022. PLEASENOTE: Requesters seekingresponsive records from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) areencouraged to create a DHS FOIA Public Access Link (PAL) accountat: . Creating a PALaccount will allow you to directly submit your FOIA request to ICE and trackthe status of your request. In PAL, you can view your prior PAL submissions,sent correspondences, and responsive records. Although PAL is preferred, ICEFOIA will continue to accept FOIA requests via email at (https://foiarequest.dhs.gov/) https://foiarequest.dhs.gov or via regularmail at U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Freedom ofInformation Act Office, 500 12 ICE-FOIA@ice.dhs.gov th St. SW, STOP 5009, Washington,DC 20536-5009. Due to the increasing number of FOIA requests received by this office, we may encounter some delay in processing your request. Per Section 5.5(a) of the DHS FOIA regulations, 6 C.F.R. Part 5, ICE processes FOIA requests according to their order of receipt. Although ICE’s goal is to respond within 20 business days of receipt of your request, the FOIA does permit a 10-day extension of this time period. As your request seeks numerous documents that will necessitate a thorough and wide-ranging search, ICE will invoke a 10-day extension for your request, as allowed by Title 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(B). If you care to narrow the scope of your request, please contact our office. We will make every effort to comply with your request in a timely manner. FOR COMMERCIAL REQUESTERS: Provisions of the FOIA allow us to recover part of the cost of complying with your request.  We shall charge you for records in accordance with the DHS Interim FOIA regulations as they apply to commercial requesters.  As a commercial requester, you will be charged 10 cents per page for duplication, and for search and review time at the per quarter-hour rate ($4.00 for clerical personnel, $7.00 for professional personnel, $10.25 for managerial personnel) of the searcher and reviewer.  We will construe the submission of your request as an agreement to pay up to $25.00. You will be contacted before any further fees are accrued. We have queried the appropriate program offices within ICE for responsive records. If any responsive records are located, they will be reviewed for determination of releasability. Please be assured that one of the processors in our office will respond to your request as expeditiously as possible. We appreciate your patience as we proceed with your request. 
Your request has been assigned reference number 2022-ICFO-14106. Please refer to this identifier in any future correspondence. To check the status of an ICE FOIA/PA request, please visit . Please note that to check the status of a request, you must enter the 2022-ICFO-14106 tracking number. If you need any further assistance or would like to discuss any aspect of your request, please contact the FOIA office. You may send an e-mail to ice-foia@ice.dhs.gov, call toll free (866) 633-1182, or you may contact our FOIA Public Liaison, Marcus Francis, in the same manner. Additionally, you have a right to right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation. If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974. You may contact OGIS as follows: Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448; or facsimile at 202-741-5769. (http://www.dhs.gov/foia-status) http://www.dhs.gov/foia-status
Regards, 

ICE FOIA Office 
Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Freedom of Information Act Office 
500 12th Street, S.W., Stop 5009 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5009 
Telephone: 1-866-633-1182 
Visit our FOIA website at www.ice.gov/foia

You may send an e-mail to ice-foia@ice.dhs.gov, call toll free (866) 633-1182, or you may contact our FOIA Public Liaison, Marcus Francis, in the same manner. communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2022-ICFO-14106
communications.communication:
Andrew Free 
MuckRock News DEPT MR 122335, 411A Highland Ave 
Somerville, Massachusetts 02144-2516 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2022-ICFO-14106 

Dear Requester: 

This letter is the final response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), dated 12/22/2021.  You have requested all records pertaining to FOIA request 2021-ICFO-32710. This request includes, but is not limited to search taskings, processing notes, and communication regarding the agency’s processing and response.. ICE has considered your request under the FOIA, 5 U.S.C. § 552. 

ICE considered the foreseeable harm standard when reviewing the record set and has applied the FOIA exemptions as required by the statute and the Attorney General’s Guidance. 

A search of the ICE Office of the Freedom of Information Act for records responsive to your request produced 17 pages that are responsive to your request.  After review of those documents, I have determined portions of 16 pages will be withheld pursuant to Exemptions of the FOIA as described below. 

ICE has applied FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7(C) to protect from disclosure the names, e-mail addresses, and phone numbers of DHS employees, as well as other third-party information contained within the documents. 

FOIA Exemption 6 exempts from disclosure personnel or medical files and similar files the release of which would cause a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.  This requires a balancing of the public’s right to disclosure against the individual’s right to privacy.  The privacy interests of the individuals in the records you have requested outweigh any minimal public interest in disclosure of the information.  Any private interest you may have in that information does not factor into the aforementioned balancing test. 

FOIA Exemption 7(C) protects records or information compiled for law enforcement purposes that could reasonably be expected to constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.  This exemption takes particular note of the strong interests of individuals, whether they are suspects, witnesses, or investigators, in not being unwarrantably associated with alleged criminal activity.  That interest extends to persons who are not only the subjects of the investigation, but those who may have their privacy invaded by having their identities and information about them revealed in connection with an investigation.  Based upon the traditional recognition of strong privacy interest in law enforcement records, categorical withholding of information that identifies third parties in law enforcement records is ordinarily appropriate.  As such, I have determined that the privacy interest in the identities of individuals in the records you have requested clearly outweigh any minimal public interest in disclosure of the information.  Please note that any private interest you may have in that information does not factor into this determination. 

ICE has applied FOIA Exemption 7(E) to protect from disclosure internal agency case numbers and internal agency URLs contained within the document. 

FOIA Exemption 7(E) protects records compiled for law enforcement purposes, the release of which would disclose techniques and/or procedures for law enforcement investigations or prosecutions, or would disclose guidelines for law enforcement investigations or prosecutions if such disclosure could reasonably be expected to risk circumvention of the law.  I have determined that disclosure of certain law enforcement sensitive information contained within the responsive records could reasonably be expected to risk circumvention of the law.  Additionally, the techniques and procedures at issue are not well known to the public. 

You have a right to appeal the above withholding determination.  Should you wish to do so, you must send your appeal and a copy of this letter, within 90 days of the date of this letter following the procedures outlined in the DHS FOIA regulations at 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.8. You may submit your appeal electronically at GILDFOIAAppeals@ice.dhs.gov or via regular mail to: 

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security 
500 12th Street, S.W., Mail Stop 5900 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5900 

Your envelope and letter should be marked “FOIA Appeal.”  Copies of the FOIA and DHS regulations are available at www.dhs.gov/foia. 

Provisions of FOIA allow DHS to charge for processing fees, up to $25, unless you seek a waiver of fees.  In this instance, because the cost is below the $25 minimum, there is no charge. 

If you have any questions please contact FOIA Public Liaison Daniel Edgington at (866) 633-1182 or 500 12th St., SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009.  Additionally, you have a right to right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Sincerely, 

Megan Davis 
Deputy FOIA Officer, Operations 

Enclosure(s):	22 Pages 
Note: If you are receiving this message by email and responsive records are not included as an attachment to the email, please log in to your SecureRelease portal account to view the responsive records.

files.source: Immigration and Customs Enforcement, United States of America

title: Flats at Paducah FOIA Request

communications.subject: Kentucky Open Records Act Request: Flats at Paducah FOIA Request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Kentucky Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

For 2057 Holt Road A-F Paducah KY 
Zoning/Building Code Violations:  Please provide notice and summary of any open/outstanding zoning/building code violations, or confirmation that none currently exist.

Fire Code Violations:  Please provide notice and summary of any open/outstanding fire code violations, or confirmation that none currently exist.

Certificates of Occupancy: Please provide any copies of the Certificate of Occupancy on file. If there are none available, please state the reason for their absence, and whether the lack of COs would give rise to any enforcement action or constitute a code violation.

Approved Site Plan and/or Conditions of Approval, if applicable:
Are there any available approval documents on file, such as planned development documents, variances, special use permits, exceptions, site-specific resolution/conditions of approval? Please provide any copies. Was this property subject to any site plan approval? Please provide any copies

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Elaina Pesce

communications.subject: RE: Kentucky Open Records Act Request: Flats at Paducah FOIA Request
communications.communication:
Attached is the site plan.  There are no known zoning violations.

The building inspector will have to answer any questions regarding COs or building violations.  He is copied on this email.

All fire code questions will have to be sent to the state fire marshal’s office in Frankfort KY

Gregory Cannon
Planning and Zoning Administrator
270-448-0125

communications.subject: Arizona Public Records Law Request: Request for Body Cam Footage of Incident – Sergio Nino
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Arizona Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Incident Details for Footage Retrieval:

Date: January 23, 2024
Suspect: Sergio Nino, 16 (at the time of the incident)
Incident Summary:
Officers Kristofer Gries, Blake Willer, and Matthew Smith responded to a call from Nino’s father regarding a family dispute. Bodycam footage reportedly captures officers encouraging Nino’s father to physically discipline him, dismissing allegations of abuse, and making statements such as "Your dad should beat you" and "You have no rights." A confrontation ensued when Officer Willer attempted to take Nino’s phone, resulting in officers using force against him. Nino suffered a broken wrist, facial lacerations requiring stitches, and was subsequently hospitalized. He was charged with aggravated assault, though charges were later dropped.
I am requesting copies of all body-worn camera footage from officers who:

Spoke with Sergio Nino’s father before engaging with the teenager.
Interacted with Sergio Nino, including advising his father on discipline.
Used force on Nino, leading to his injuries and subsequent arrest.
Transported Nino from the scene to medical facilities or booking.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Harun

title: SWAT Call Outs (Orange County Sheriff's Office)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: SWAT Call Outs (Orange County Sheriff's Office)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records related to SWAT call-outs:
SWAT includes SEB or any similar division at your agency
Data recorded by the department into a database or in reports that have:
- the deployment reasons/nature of each SWAT call-out (mental health, barricaded suspect, assist with federal or local partners, etc)
- any use of force, including the use of tear-gas and explosive breaching rounds
- deployment of any specialized equipment (drones, MRAPs)
- conclusion of call 
- dates
I don't need information on the who of the investigations; I need the what (use of force, specialized equipment) and why (deployment reason, conclusion of call) of each deployment. 

Please keep in native .csv if it's from a database.

Search 2024

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

title: Greenbrier County Opioid Settlement Funds

communications.subject: West Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Greenbrier County Opioid Settlement Funds
communications.communication:
Spencer Yoke
1511 Univesity Ave
Morgantown, WV 26505

03/06/2025

Jamie Baker 
Greenbrier County Clerk
Greenbrier County Gov’t
200 N Court St
Lewisburg, WV 24901

To Jamie Baker, 

Pursuant to the state open records law W.Va. Code Secs. 29B-1-1 to 29B-1-7, I write to request access to public records regarding Greenbrier County’s opioid settlement funds. Specifically, I am requesting copies of: 

The amount of funds Greenbrier County has received so far
The application to apply for funding
The individuals who will review the funding applications
The process by which funds will be awarded
Documents or other information detailing how the opioid settlement funds distributed to Greenbrier County have been awarded through March 1, 2025, if at all, including budgets, grant allocations, and expenditure reports.
Any existing or proposed plans outlining future use of said opioid settlement funds, including strategic plans, meeting minutes in which county-level officials participated, and correspondence and attachments regarding funding allocations.
Any public reports, audits, or documentation created by the county regarding the accountability and impact of these funds
All attachments, addendums, appendices, exhibits, and other related documents that were included as part of the contracts.

If your agency does not maintain these public records, please let me know who does and include the proper custodian's name and address.
As provided by the open records law, I will expect your response within five (5) working days. See W. Va. Code Sec. 29B-1-3(d).
If you choose to deny this request, please provide a written explanation for the denial including a reference to the specific statutory exemption(s) upon which you rely. Also, please provide all segregable portions of otherwise exempt material.
I would note that willful violation of the open records law is a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than $200 nor more than $1,000, or imprisonment in the county jail for twenty (20) days, or both. See W. Va. Code Sec. 29B-1-6. Court costs and attorney fees may also be awarded. See Sec. 29B-1-7.
Thank you for your assistance.

Sincerely,

Spencer J. Yoke
West Virginia University
(304)685-9637
sjy00001@mix.wvu.edu

Joe Darnell

Greenbrier County Assessor

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the South Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

A list of officers within State Transport Police who received an “Unsatisfactory” rating in any category during the Fiscal Year 2024 Employee Performance Management System (EPMS) review process.

For each officer, please include:
Officer name
Rank or title
Troop/region assignment
The category or categories where an “Unsatisfactory” was recorded

If available, any relevant performance metric associated with the rating (e.g. number of inspections completed during the rating period)

I am not requesting any full evaluation forms or narrative comments—only the structured fields as listed above.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Edwin Chadwick

title: Medical Policies for Blood Borne Pathogens (Yuma County Sheriff's Office)

communications.subject: Arizona Public Records Law Request: Medical Policies for Blood Borne Pathogens (Yuma County Sheriff's Office)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Arizona Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

1- Any directives, regulations, manuals, memos, or other training materials given to all staff—both medical and correctional—related to handling or managing prisoners with blood borne pathogens including but not limited Hepatitis C or HIV/AIDS.  This could be in the form of training materials on how to quarantine individuals with blood borne pathogens, or training materials for correctional staff on what to do when coming into contact with someone who has a blood borne pathogen. 

2- Any emergency preparedness manuals, directives, or training materials for when a viral outbreak occurs (this could also be referred to as a “pandemic procedure".)

3- Any medical directives, memos, regulations, or staff training around prescribing the medical protocol of PrEP (pre-exposure prophylaxis).

4- Any directives, regulations, manuals, memos, or other training materials given to staff on housing criteria for specific populations (e.g. women, youth, those with illnesses, etc.)

5- Employee handbook given to correctional staff upon hiring, as well as any employee handbook given separately to medical staff

I am also requesting the following data and forms:

1- Aggregate data by month on the number of prisoners with HIV and Hep C for the last two years. If this data exists only in a format that requires creation of a new record, please provide the data in its original format and remove identifying information.

2- A copy of the standard medical intake form used for prisoners or people held inside the facility.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Joseph Darius Jaafari

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following Arizona Public Records Law request, copied below, and originally submitted on April 3, 2025. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

1.Any directives, regulations, manuals, memos, or other training materials given to all staff—both medical and correctional—related to handling or managing prisoners with blood borne pathogens including but not limited Hepatitis C or HIV/AIDS. This could be in the form of training materials on how to quarantine individuals with blood borne pathogens, or training materials for correctional staff on what to do when coming into contact with someone who has a blood borne pathogen.  

•         NSC CPR/First Aid Training 

2- Any emergency preparedness manuals, directives, or training materials for when a viral outbreak occurs (this could also be referred to as a “pandemic procedure".) 

•         Per facility as per recommendations by Licensed Medical Director’s discretion and based on each situation circumstance. 

3- Any medical directives, memos, regulations, or staff training around prescribing the medical protocol of PrEP (pre-exposure prophylaxis). 

•         No set protocol - Care provided is per Licensed Provider recommendation and is based on individual treatment plan

4- Any directives, regulations, manuals, memos, or other training materials given to staff on housing criteria for specific populations (e.g. women, youth, those with illnesses, etc.)

•         See attached.

5- Employee handbook given to correctional staff upon hiring, as well as any employee handbook given separately to medical staff-See 

*       Attached

I am also requesting the following data and forms:
1-      Aggregate data by month on the number of prisoners with HIV and Hep C for the last two years. If this data exists only in a format that requires creation of a new record, please provide the data in its original format and remove identifying information. 

•         To date, we have had 33 inmates identified to be HIV positive that were booked in the last two years

·         To date, we have had 103 inmates identified to have Hep C (both cured/untreated) that were booked in the last two years

·         Month to month data is not available  at this time as the data is directly connected to identifying information 

2- A copy of the standard medical intake form used for prisoners or people held inside the facility.

 Attached.

title: Public Records Request: ForceMetrics

communications.subject: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: Public Records Request: ForceMetrics
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the North Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

- All contracts, licenses, MOUs, MOAs, data agreements, letters of intent, State of Work documents, Scope of Work documents, and other agreement documents with ForceMetrics that were active any time between 1/1/2021 and 3/18/2025.
- All financial documents or records of financial transactions, exchanges or obligations related to ForceMetrics. Responsive materials include all invoices, bills, receipts, check stubs, or any other records, including those possessed in an electronic format.
- A copy of all training materials, including but not limited to any handouts, workbooks, assessments, presentations, slides, videos, audio files, or other materials, either developed in-house or provided to the agency pertaining to the agency's use of ForceMetrics products.
- A copy of all agency manuals either developed in-house or provided to the agency pertaining to the agency's use of ForceMetrics products.
- A copy of all agency policies and procedures either developed in-house or provided to the agency pertaining to the agency's use of ForceMetrics products.
- A roster of all agency employees who either have a user account for ForceMetrics products or have internal agency permissions to use ForceMetrics products as of 3/18/2025.
- A roster of all agency employees who have completed agency training for the use of  ForceMetrics products as of 3/18/2025.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

e

title: Kathleen Autry Arrest – February 10, 2025

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Kathleen Autry Arrest – February 10, 2025
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting all records related to the arrest of Kathleen J. Autry on February 10, 2025, at approximately 6:20 PM, by the Clearwater Police Department in Clearwater, Florida.

According to public records, Autry was arrested and charged with the following:

Possession of Marijuana Wax

Violation of Probation – Neglect of a Child (x2)

I am specifically requesting:

The complete arrest and incident reports, including officer narratives, probable cause affidavits, and any child welfare-related documentation

Any available body-worn camera (BWC) footage recorded during the arrest

Any 911 call recordings, CAD logs, or dispatch notes related to the incident

Photographs, videos, or evidence documentation collected during the investigation

Any documentation submitted to or by the Florida Department of Children and Families (DCF) if applicable

Given the nature of the charges involving both drug possession and child neglect, this request is submitted in the public interest to better understand the law enforcement and child protection response.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Thomas Jackson

Hello Clearwater Police Records Team,

Thank you for releasing the requested records. Unfortunately, I have not been able to access them:

I have not received an email from the digital evidence program (www.evidence.com) with the download link, or

If an email was sent, it may have been blocked or filtered before it reached me.

Could you please re-send the Evidence.com link—or provide another way for me to obtain the files? If possible, let me know the date and sender address the original email came from so I can search my spam and quarantine folders.

I appreciate your help. If you need any additional information to verify my request, just let me know.

Thank you,
Thomas Jackson

title: Public Information Request: Anti-Gang Center Grant 2023-2024

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Public Information Request: Anti-Gang Center Grant 2023-2024
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

According to responsive records from Gov. Abbot's office, the City of El Paso received a grant of $4,613,209.85 for the "Texas Anti Gang Center" with a grant start date of 9/1/2023.

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of all documents, including but not limited to, applications, agreements, and reporting documents related to the $4,613,209.85, awarded for the "Texas Anti-Gang Program, FY2024" submitted to the Governor's Public Safety Office.  

This request is not seeking further documentation beyond the list of awardees and amount awarded to each.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

e

title: Boston Police Email Addresses (City of Boston, Law Department)

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Boston Police Email Addresses (City of Boston, Law Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

I request a list of email addresses for all active Boston Police Department officers, including officer rank/title, Officer assignment or department if available.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Records Requester

communications.subject: Police Records Request :: B001141-042325
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST B001141-042325 created 4/23/2025 9:09:47 AM Dear Records Requester, The Boston Police Department (Department) has received your request for public records.  This response applies only to records that exist and are in the custody of the City.  See A Guide to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, p. 32, n.115.  It is expected that a custodian of records must use her superior knowledge of her records with respect to responses to public records requests.  950 CMR 32.04(5).  Specifically, you requested: I request a list of email addresses for all active Boston Police Department officers, including officer rank/title, Officer assignment or department if available. We have reviewed our files and have located records that correspond to your request. I am checking to see if we have a list of email addresses and will get back to you. But for the list of names and rank, please go to https://data.boston.gov/dataset/employee-earnings-report You may appeal this response to the Supervisor of Records in the Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth. G. L. c. 66, § 10A (c); G. L. c. 66, § 10(b)(ix); 950 CMR 32.08; 950 CMR 32.08(1)(h) (in petitioning the Supervisor, the requester shall provide a copy of such petition to the records access officer associated with such petition).  You may also appeal to the Superior Court.  950 CMR 32.06(3)(c). Thank you. 
To monitor the progress or update this request please log into the Public Records Center. (https://u8387778.ct.sendgrid.net/ls/click?upn=u001.VEsWrlMiJDg0mXafq1mEXTIDeIcW7QPGcxbg2r6mBl4IQAtcuUR-2B6-2B48u6MWdi-2FuNfsoFtzUO-2FiE2Z5NHdOxR8S4-2BUBVhRBHHVYKZbupVJk7uRnLLIamhDhW2l1hygj394aE_SMDR7-2FuvTDRbNSt-2FdsqBsq6YyLd9KBUS2IXIbFuFxxxkzTAc3dfMKOZEwYQiA73Mb5TkdVTcMPetBdc9wfbt3J8j9Xq-2Bj0H07gULRejb055BFKgVSp00z5OUg4THdlcMhYl6Zf-2BnXCj6-2BODj7D-2FbL6VSP6KOK32yXlR-2FR-2FbJ4upi02BGBXB21GeYTfU-2F1MYK6-2BeM52cxHRce2agpKsTXgvIBuqzCzfCJmMyyY-2FDrRCc3TYfkq6bLBIw4L1vKQGldBGh0Br3nxHFaNKHKOVzn-2FjnL9SGCIRFlNC73SelMQ-2BhtIegfeC9Xkesp-2BjJmFg9z9N7-2FED6JiMPDxWOwayAMjtKyYAWvhb30-2FaECYCfYdhK1vgtMzPdn1IAPxO6stnxT)

communications.communication:

title: Chief FOIA officer's recent email (Food and Drug Administration)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Chief FOIA officer's recent email (Food and Drug Administration)
communications.communication:
Dear Food and Drug Administration,

On behalf of myself and Fiat Fiendum, I hereby request the following records:

1. The one email in your chief FOIA officer's email inbox or equivalent which was received nearest and before October 19, 2024, midnight Eastern time, regardless of subject matter.
2. The one email in your chief FOIA officer's email spam folder or equivalent which was received nearest and before October 19, 2024, midnight Eastern time, regardless of subject matter.
3. The one email in your chief FOIA officer's sent email folder or equivalent which was sent nearest and before October 19, 2024, midnight Eastern time, regardless of subject matter.
4. The total full-time equivalent count of people who work for your FOIA office as of October 19, 2024.

This request is expressly limited to Food and Drug Administration's own FOIA office. Please do not refer it to any other agency or division. This request is expressly not a Privacy Act request, and no PA waiver will be provided.

Please provide the email records in EML, Maildir, MBOX, MIX, MSG, or PST format only — not PDF, Word, image, etc — including all metadata (e.g. full email headers as received/sent) and attachments, without alteration other than narrowly tailored electronic redaction of specifically claimed exemptions that do not affect any part of non exempt information (and, in particular, without rasterization).

Please provide the fourth record as a statement in your response letter, or at your option, as the most readily available record, in original electronic format as currently stored on your computer systems, which includes that information.

Please provide all records either as individual files, or as an unencrypted ZIP file, uploaded to MuckRock. Do not apply any encryption, DRM, or other restriction.

I request fee waiver, because
* Fiat Fiendum is a 501(c)(3) non-profit;
* this request is for public interest, non-commercial purposes;
* these records would give a snapshot of insight into the everyday processes of FOIA offices; and
* these records are being requested in order to conduct a government-wide audit of agencies' FOIA compliance.

In the event that you deny fee waiver, please process this request as-is, because I will not agree to any fees.

Please be sure to provide:
* 5 USC 552(a)(6)(A)(i)(II) FOIA Public Liaison information
* 5 USC 552(a)(6)(A)(i)(III)(aa) appeal information
* 5 USC 552(a)(6)(A)(i)(III)(bb) OGIS information
* 5 USC 552(a)(7)(A) tracking number
* 5 USC 552(a)(7)(B)(ii) completion ETA

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,
Sai
President, Fiat Fiendum, Inc.

P.S. Sai is my full legal name.

Reference: FDA24108085 
Dear Requester, 
This is to confirm that you submitted a request for record(s) from the Food and Drug Administration
pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act. 
FOIA staff will review your request to determine whether it has sufficient information to be processed;
if so, you will receive another email as a formal acknowledgement of your request, with a control number for your request. 
If your request is not sufficiently described,
or if there are any other deficiencies with your submission, FOIA staff will contact you via telephone or email.

Regarding items 1 through 3, the Chief FOIA Officer is Jeffrey Nesbit, who is with HHS. We will refer your request to the HHS FOIA office for response to you.

title: Emails Christian & Parks

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Emails Christian & Parks
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Any and all emails, other correspondence and records between Alison T. Christian and the Chicago Park District between March 15, 2025 and April 14, 2025.

Please include in your search as responsive records: communications, memorandums, background papers, meeting minutes, or email exchanges. If your office has questions about this request, please feel free to direct them to the address associated with this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Alexandra Gelzin

title: National Nuclear Security Administration support for film "Oppenheimer" (2023) (National Nuclear Security Administration)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: National Nuclear Security Administration support for film "Oppenheimer" (2023) (National Nuclear Security Administration)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any documents pertaining to National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA) support for or collaboration with the production of the 2023 movie "Oppenheimer," directed by Christopher Nolan. Such collaboration or support includes but is not limited to permission to use NNSA facilities and access to technical assistance from NNSA employees.

I request a search of all locations where such documents might be located, including but not limited to the entertainment liaison offices and communications HQ or similar offices. Such documents may include, but are not limited to, script notes; production assistance agreements; and all records of communications between employees of the NNSA and members of the cast, crew, and production company of "Oppenheimer," including memos, notes of meetings and conference calls, emails, and other forms of communication.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation. These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #FOIA 24-00136-LB
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern,

On January 22, 2024, I submitted a FOIA request (24-00136-LB) with the National Nuclear Security Administration requesting documents pertaining to their support for the production of the 2023 “Oppenheimer” movie, directed by Christopher Nolan. On June 28, 2024, FOIA specialist Lora Bright wrote to me: “I’m pending a response from one more program office and I’m hoping to have our response to you by October 31, 2024.” This date came and went, and in response to my further query, she wrote, on October 31, 2024: “We are finalizing our response to you. I expect to have it completed by November 30, 2024.”

This date also came and went, and all of my follow up messages (five so far) have been ignored. I also called and left a phone message with this FOIA specialist, which was also ignored. 

In 2022, some months before the release of Nolan’s “Oppenheimer” film, then-Secretary of Energy Jennifer Granholm announced that DOE had “vacated” the Atomic Energy Commission’s finding that Dr. Oppenheimer’s security clearance should be revoked:

https://www.energy.gov/articles/secretary-granholm-statement-doe-order-vacating-1954-atomic-energy-commission-decision

 This decision appeared to be timed to coincide with the release of the film, which goes out of its way to underscore Dr. Oppenheimer’s innocence. 

Moreover, I made the request with NNSA after a FOIA specialist indicated to me on the phone (in connection with a different DOE FOIA request) that the production of “Oppenheimer” used US government nuclear facilities. 

There is reason to suspect, therefore, that the government is deliberately delaying the release of these documents, which would demonstrate a close collaboration between the government and the production team, lest public disclosure of said collaboration undermine the film’s historically dubious messaging—messaging which was already endorsed by DOE before the release of the film. The delay, in fact, has already undermined the public’s ability to scrutinize this messaging, since the film has long since moved from the center of public consciousness.

I am therefore appealing the constructive denial of my request and asking that the agency respond to my request forthwith, providing the documents requested or outlining reasons that they are exempt.

Respectfully,

Brett Carollo

title: Imperial Calls

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Imperial Calls
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. A printout or log or similar record of all emergency and non-emergency calls or requests for service to the Imperial County Sheriff's Office from the Imperial Regional Detention Center, located at 1572 Gateway Rd, Calexico, CA 92231, for the period beginning February 7, 2024, and continuing through March 20, 2025.

2. If the Imperial County Sheriff's Office is the custodian of records for 911 call logs, a log of 911 calls from the Imperial Regional Detention Center received between February 7, 2024, and March 20, 2025.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

title: Daijah Cano Arrest – May 13, 2023

communications.subject: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Daijah Cano Arrest – May 13, 2023
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting all records related to the arrest of Daijah Cano on May 13, 2023, at approximately 12:31 AM, at or near 1200 Milton, Doña Ana County, NM, by the Las Cruces Police Department (LCPD).

Specifically, I am seeking:

The arrest report, including officer narratives, probable cause statements, and any citations or charges filed

Any body-worn camera (BWC) footage recorded by arresting or responding officers

The 911 call audio and transcript, if one was made in connection with this incident

Any booking photos (mugshots) and related documentation

Any dispatch records or CAD logs for this incident

This request is made in the interest of transparency and public accountability in routine law enforcement actions.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Thomas Jackson

The purpose of this message is to provide you with a notification relating to the Inspection of Public Records Act (hereinafter “IPRA”) request you provided the City of Las Cruces (hereinafter “City” or “Las Cruces”). Under NMSA 1978, § 14-2-8, the City has determined that it does not have possession of and/or responsibility for the 911 call recordings or any other dispatch records that you have requested.  However, the City knows the proper custodian of these records to be Mesilla Valley Regional Dispatch Authority (MVRDA), 911 Lake Tahoe Ct., Las Cruces, NM, 88007, (575) 526-0795, https://www.mvrda.org/records-request-instructions/.  Under NMSA 1978, § 14-2-8, the City has also determined that it does not have possession of and/or responsibility for the booking photos or any other detention center records that you have requested. However, the City also knows the proper custodian of these records to be Doña Ana County (DAC), 845 N. Motel Blvd, Las Cruces, NM, 88007, 575-647-7600, https://recordbook.donaanacounty.org/home.  As such, on April 7, 2025 the City forwarded your request to MVRDA and DAC.  To expedite your request, you may consider submitting an additional records request to those agency's records custodians directly,  In light of this notification, the City considers the request for dispatch records closed. Thank you for your attention. Should you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact our office. 
Please note that t he City will continue to search and review documents in response to the remainder of your request. Sincerely, 
Christine Rivera

I am requesting all records related to the arrest of Daijah Cano on May 13, 2023, at approximately 12:31 AM, at or near 1200 Milton, Doña Ana County, NM, by the Las Cruces Police Department (LCPD).

RE: Police Records Request, Reference # P000732-040625 Dear Thomas Jackson, The City of Las Cruces received the following public records request from you on April 07, 2025: To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

I am requesting all records related to the arrest of Daijah Cano on May 13, 2023, at approximately 12:31 AM, at or near 1200 Milton, Doña Ana County, NM, by the Las Cruces Police Department (LCPD). 

Specifically, I am seeking: 

The arrest report, including officer narratives, probable cause statements, and any citations or charges filed 

Any body-worn camera (BWC) footage recorded by arresting or responding officers 

The 911 call audio and transcript, if one was made in connection with this incident 

Any booking photos (mugshots) and related documentation 

Any dispatch records or CAD logs for this incident 

This request is made in the interest of transparency and public accountability in routine law enforcement actions. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Thomas Jackson 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Flas-cruces-new-mexico-police-department-4431%252Fdaijah-cano-arrest-may-13-2023-184476%252F%253Femail%253Dkperalta%252540las-cruces.org&url_auth_token=AAAWk2FNE129jWDSFr7SU9dcyI4%3A1u1cCG%3A5PuP2nkpn6mu6Jnm5KeSvQ_UI6bHOLlxbrqmb5RYI5Y 
The purpose of this message is to provide you with a partial response to the Inspection of Public Records Act (hereinafter “IPRA”) request you provided the City of Las Cruces (hereinafter “City” or “Las Cruces”). The City has gathered, reviewed, and appropriately redacted the following public records associated with your request: 
One (1) document and four (4) videos 
 
  *  New Mexico Statutes Annotated (hereinafter “NMSA”) Section 14-2-1.1 states “Protected personal identifier information contained in public records may be redacted by a public body before inspection or copying of a record.” The term “protected personal identifier information” is defined within NMSA Section 14-2-6(F) to include:  (1) all but the last four digits of a: (a) taxpayer identification number;  (b) financial account number; (c) credit or debit card number; or (d) driver’s license number;  (2) all but the year of a person’s date of birth; (3) a social security number; and (4) with regard to a nonelected employee of a public body in the context of the person’s employment, the employee’s nonbusiness home street address, but not the city, state or zip code;  therefore, any of the above-described “protected personal identifier information” found within the responsive records have been redacted. 
  *  New Mexico Statutes Annotated (hereinafter “NMSA”) 1978, § 14-2-1.2(A)(8) states, in pertinent part, that “Law enforcement records are public records, except “records pertaining to physical or mental examination and medical treatment of persons unless the information could be relevant to a criminal investigation or an investigation of misfeasance, malfeasance or other suspected violation of law conducted by a person elected to or employed by a public body,” and therefore, such records “may be redacted from a written record or digitally obscured in a visual or audio record.” Therefore, any medical records and/or the discussion of medical diagnosis found within the responsive records have been redacted. New Mexico Statutes Annotated (hereinafter “NMSA”) 1978, § 14-2-1(J) states that every person has a right to inspect public records of this state except “information concerning information technology systems, the publication of which would reveal specific vulnerabilities that compromise or allow unlawful access to such systems; provided that this subsection shall not be used to restrict requests for (1) records stored or transmitted using information technology systems and (2) internal and external audits of information technology systems, except for those portions that would reveal ongoing vulnerabilities that compromise or allow unlawful access to such systems.” Therefore, any records that would disclose methods for unlawfully accessing technology systems contained within the responsive records have been redacted. A download link with the contents of this request has been e-mailed to you from AXON.  This download link expires in three (3) days. Please contact our office by replying to this email or via telephone if you have any issues accessing the documents or if you wish to receive the documents in another format. Pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 14-2-10, the City has determined that your written request is excessively burdensome and/or broad. More specifically, the City has determined that it requires an additional reasonable period of time to gather, review, and appropriately redact any and all public records associated with your request.  Although the City cannot anticipate when the remainder of the responsive records associated with your request will become available, the City will produce them within a reasonable period of time. Further, the City will provide a written status update regarding your request within fifteen (15) days. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. Should you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact my office. Sincerely, 
Christine Rivera 
Records Custodian 
(575) 541-2112

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request #P000732-040625
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Rivera,

Thank you for your continued assistance in fulfilling IPRA Request #P000732-040625 regarding the arrest of Daijah Cano on May 13, 2023.

As part of the records previously requested, I would like to confirm whether the full incident narrative or officer’s written report is available and included in the responsive materials. If it has not yet been provided, I respectfully request that it be included in the remaining documents to be released.

The incident narrative is essential for understanding the context and circumstances surrounding the arrest and is specifically sought under the portion of the request referencing “officer narratives” and “probable cause statements.”

Please advise if this document is available or if additional time is required to locate and produce it.

Thank you again for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Thomas Jackson

title: Echo Summit Highway 50 landslide March 2022 (California Department of Transportation (Caltrans))

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Echo Summit Highway 50 landslide March 2022 (California Department of Transportation (Caltrans))
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records, receipts, photographs, and documentary materials referencing a landslide that fell onto highway 50 Echo summit from dates of March 3, 2022 to March 6, 2022. I am also requesting documents detailing the process of removal of said landslide including documents referencing the explosives used to clear the large boulders and any receipts of costs associated with it. 

For reference, a large landslide blocked all traffic on the highway for days, before it was blasted with explosives. A news link to this can be found here. https://www.ktvu.com/news/tumbling-boulders-block-highway-50-at-echo-summit-make-travel-treacherous.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Katherine Fulwider

On October 15, 2024, the California Department of Transportation (Caltrans) received your request for records under the Public Records Act (PRA) wherein you requested the following: To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

Records, receipts, photographs, and documentary materials referencing a landslide that fell onto highway 50 Echo summit from dates of March 3, 2022 to March 6, 2022. I am also requesting documents detailing the process of removal of said landslide including documents referencing the explosives used to clear the large boulders and any receipts of costs associated with it. 

For reference, a large landslide blocked all traffic on the highway for days, before it was blasted with explosives. A news link to this can be found here. https://www.ktvu.com/news/tumbling-boulders-block-highway-50-at-echo-summit-make-travel-treacherous. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Katherine Fulwider

RE: Public Records Request of October 15, 2024, Reference # R035942-101524 
Dear Katherine Fulwider, 
On October 15, 2024, the California Department of Transportation (Caltrans) received your request for records under the Public Records Act wherein you requested the following: To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

Records, receipts, photographs, and documentary materials referencing a landslide that fell onto highway 50 Echo summit from dates of March 3, 2022 to March 6, 2022. I am also requesting documents detailing the process of removal of said landslide including documents referencing the explosives used to clear the large boulders and any receipts of costs associated with it. 

For reference, a large landslide blocked all traffic on the highway for days, before it was blasted with explosives. A news link to this can be found here. https://www.ktvu.com/news/tumbling-boulders-block-highway-50-at-echo-summit-make-travel-treacherous. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Katherine Fulwider 
We have located the records responsive to your request, and those records are available in the Public Records Center .  Please log in to your online account and retrieve the records. When it was reported that large boulders had fallen onto U.S. Highway 50 (U.S. 50), Caltrans, in cooperation with the California Highway Patrol (CHP), immediately closed the highway to protect the public. Safety is Caltrans’ top priority. Caltrans has procedures in place to securely remove road hazards and keep all highways safe for motorists. U.S. 50 just east of Echo Summit has been historically susceptible to rockslides due to its topography. During the winter of 2022, the hillside above the highway was particularly vulnerable from winter storms due to the Caldor Fire that burned over Echo Summit along the highway in August and September of 2021. In the months after the fire, Caltrans crews worked with a contractor to conduct rock scaling operations to lessen the potential for rockslides, as hundreds of trees that help stabilize the hillsides were destroyed in the blaze. Caltrans’ rapid response in cooperation with the CHP helped ensure the safety of the traveling public. Caltrans closely monitors Echo Summit and removes loose rocks that pose a hazard to U.S. 50. Highway safety is a key part of Caltrans’ 2024-2025 strategic plan, and our vision is zero deaths and serious injuries on California’s roads by 2050. Caltrans has adopted the Safe System Approach, which seeks to design roadway environments that mitigate human mistakes and encourage safer behaviors. Caltrans is committed to maintaining and improving the state’s transportation network to make it safer, more reliable and more resilient. For more information on the Safe System Approach, click here Please let me know if you have any question s. Sincerely, John O’Connell 
Caltrans District 3 CPRA Coordinator (530) 701-9459

title: FBI support for 2016- ID series "People Magazine Investigates" (2019-2023)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FBI support for 2016- ID series "People Magazine Investigates" (2019-2023)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All documents pertaining to FBI support for or collaboration with the production of the 2016- Investigation Discovery series "People Magazine Investigates," from 2019-2023. Such documents may include, but are not limited to, script notes; production assistance agreements; and all records of communications between employees of the FBI and members of the cast, crew, and production company of "People Magazine Investigates," including memos, notes of meetings and conference calls, emails, and other forms of communication. I request a search of all locations where such documents might be located, including but not limited to the entertainment liaison offices and communications HQ or similar offices.

Attached is a document, released to me by the FBI in response to a previous FOIA request, confirming that the FBI supported the production of "People Magazine Investigates," between 2019 and 2023.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation. These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

title: Health Services Policy Manual

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Health Services Policy Manual
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

1) The current and complete Health Services Policy Manual as established by DOCCS directive #4300. 

2) Documents and memos regarding changes to the Health Services Policy Manual between January 2020 and August 2023.

3) Documents regarding all approved adaptations to, exceptions to and departures from the Health Services Policy Manual specific to the following facilities: Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, Taconic Correctional Facility and Albion Correctional Facility.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Molly Hagan

I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.Sincerely,Molly HaganUpload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fdepartment-of-corrections-and-community-supervision-new-york-state-23367%252Fhealth-services-policy-manual-150171%252F%253Femail%253DFOIL%252540doccs.ny.gov&url_auth_token=AADrKv4s9BocwJREzMDOXZWr574%3A1qRkru%3AK2HN6kwvlcevioKCLr91m_F9l11xrujkqBtbtBaPTlg

title: Labor Standards Complaint Forms (LS223) filed on employers in Delaware County

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Labor Standards Complaint Forms (LS223) filed on employers in Delaware County
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Copies of all Labor Standards Complaint Forms (LS223) filed by employees of businesses located in Delaware County, NY, since 1996, including companies owned and operated by parent companies in other regions of the United States and the world with facilities in Delaware County. Additionally, I would like to request any and all records pertaining to Task Force Hotline reports of lack of safety equipment, retaliation, forced labor, or other issues filed via telephone by employees of companies located in Delaware County, NY, since 1996.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Anne Elizabeth Moore

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fnew-york-state-department-labor-4385%252Flabor-standards-complaint-forms-ls223-filed-on-employers-in-delaware-county-172803%252F%253Femail%253Dfoil%252540labor.ny.gov&url_auth_token=AAAXX-hx3MeDsgGxu1jfBSeuOqw%3A1slJMC%3AtCpHXPwAfk8mvDbr6aOh6YLvGXPvgVyrjss6nmYq_SM The New York State Department of Labor has reviewed its files and has located records that are responsive to your request. Please be advised that access is denied to information which “would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy" pursuant to Public Officers Law §§ 87(2)(b), 89(2)(b), and 96(1). Department of Labor | FOIL Records Access Center  You may submit a written appeal of this decision within 30 days by mail to: Commissioner of Labor, New York State Department of Labor, Harriman State Office Campus, Building 12, Room 500, Albany, NY 12226.  You must state a basis for appeal, attach a copy of this letter, and mark the letter and envelope as “FOIL Appeal.” If you are unable to access these records, please call our office at 518-485-2191. title: 2010, 2011 and 2015 Crime Incident Requests

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: 2010, 2011 and 2015 Crime Incident Requests
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting data on crime incidents—those classified by your agency as crimes—rather than calls for service or unfounded incidents.
• Year(s) Requested: 2010, 2011 and 2015
• Columns Requested: Incident date, Incident time, Type of crime (e.g., robbery, theft, etc.), Incident ID, and all other available columns that do not require additional processing by the agency or redaction.

If the data are stored in a proprietary or custom electronic format not publicly available, I request that it be converted to a format viewable with standard software, such as Microsoft Excel or CSV. Please avoid providing data in PDF or paper printouts.

This request is made to support academic research conducted in the public interest and is not for commercial purposes. The data will contribute to a research project assessing the effect of music concerts on crime, aiming to enhance public understanding of how large events influence community safety.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kristina Block

5. In person at: Reno Police Department 455 E. 2nd Street Reno, NV 89501. 
If you would like for our office to proceed with your request, please provide clarifications within 10 business days from 04/10/2025. 
Upon receipt of your clarification, we will further respond to your records request as required by law, including providing you with an estimate of costs associated with producing the requested records. Otherwise, we will consider your request withdrawn. 
If you have any additional questions, please feel free to contact the Reno Police Department Records Division at 775-334-2155 ext. 0. 
Thank you for contacting the City of Reno. 
Sincerely, 
Records Division

If the estimated cost of the copies requested is $25.00 or more, the requester will be required to pay in full prior to reproduction. Materials will be held for 14 days. communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Arizona Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. A copy of any policy concerning recognition or registration of student organizations at your institution or at any institution within your district.

2. A copy of any list of active or recognized student organizations at your institution or at any institution within your district.

3. A copy of any list of contact information for active or recognized student organizations at your institution or at any institution within your district.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: Crime Incident Data Request

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Crime Incident Data Request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting data on crime incidents—those classified by your agency as crimes—rather than calls for service or unfounded incidents.
• Year(s) Requested: 2010; 2011; 2013
• Columns Requested: Incident date, Incident time, Type of crime (e.g., robbery, theft, etc.), Incident ID, and all other available columns that do not require additional processing by the agency or redaction.

If the data are stored in a proprietary or custom electronic format not publicly available, I request that it be converted to a format viewable with standard software, such as Microsoft Excel or CSV. Please avoid providing data in PDF or paper printouts.

This request is made to support academic research conducted in the public interest and is not for commercial purposes. The data will contribute to a research project assessing the effect of music concerts on crime, aiming to enhance public understanding of how large events influence community safety.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Kristina Block
