communications.subject: FW: Public Records Request Form
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

Indiana University is in receipt of your below public records request submitted pursuant to the Indiana Access to Public Records Act (APRA). In order for IU to begin processing your request, you will need to provide further information regarding the record(s) you are requesting. APRA requires that a request for inspection and/or copying must identify with reasonable particularity the record(s) being requested. I.C. 5-14-3-3(a)(1). The Indiana Court of Appeals has held that "[w]hether a request identifies with reasonable particularity the record being requested turns, in part, on whether the person making the request provides the agency with information that enables the agency to search for, locate and retrieve records." Jent v. Fort Wayne Police Dep't, 973 N.E.2d 30, 34 (Ind. Ct. App. 2012).

As currently written, your below request does not identify reasonably particular parameters that enable the University to "search for, locate and retrieve records." While the term "reasonable particularity" is not defined within APRA, I encourage you to read the many opinions of the Indiana Public Access Counselor, along with Anderson v. Huntington Cty. Bd. of Comm'rs, 983 N.E.2d 613 (Ind. Ct. App. 2013).

Per this authority, please further specify the type(s) of record(s) that you are seeking in response to your request below. Once sufficient specificity is provided, the University can begin to process your request.


Myekeal D. Wynn
Assistant General Counsel
301 University Boulevard
University Hall 5030
Indianapolis, IN 46202
[cid:image001.png@01DB941F.43671E10]

communications.subject: RE: Indiana Access to Public Records Act Request #2814278
communications.communication:
Good day, 

Please note Ind. Code § 5-14-3-1 states that ARPA is "liberally construed" and "that the burden of proof for the nondisclosure of a public record on the public agency that would deny access to the record and not on the person seeking to inspect and copy the record." I have not been informed by the agency of any reason how a search or production of these records is unreasonable.

In training materials for handling APRA requests, the Vice President and General Counsel of Indiana University defines a reasonably particular request as one "specifying the subject matter and, if relevant, dates." See Burkert, Aimee Nicole, "Indiana Access to Public Records Act (APRA) & Open Records Requests," as published July 22, 2016 at https://vpgc.iu.edu/doc/training/open_records_training_slides.pptx. 

I will reiterate that the particular scope is official correspondence dated March 4, 2025 which mentions any of the following search terms: "Executive Order 25-35"; "Executive Order 25-36"; "Title IX", "biological sex", "gender identity"; or "gender ideology." These may be electronic documents or within the bodies of email,  in those offices which deal with the Office of the Governor and/or its delegates.  

-TM

communications.subject: RE: [External] RE: Indiana Access to Public Records Act Request #2814278
communications.communication:
Hi,

A request is reasonably particular if and when it is made with sufficient particularity to allow the agency to look for the responsive records. See Jent v. Fort Wayne Police Dep't, 973 N.E.2d 30, 34 (Ind. Ct. App. 2012) ("[w]hether a request identifies with reasonable particularity the record being requested turns, in part, on whether the person making the request provides the agency with information that enables the agency to search for, locate and retrieve records.")

As of now, we do not know where to begin looking for records responsive to your request. Can you provide who, and what unit, you believe to be in possession of the responsive records.

Myekeal D. Wynn
Assistant General Counsel
301 University Boulevard
University Hall 5030
Indianapolis, IN 46202
[cid:image001.png@01DB9D86.6FA16BF0]

-TM

Thank you for providing the names of the people from whom you are seeking responsive records. Could you identify what in particular you are looking for when you say “records?”
Best,

Myekeal D. Wynn
Assistant General Counsel
301 University Boulevard
University Hall 5030
Indianapolis, IN 46202
[cid:image001.png@01DB9E41.D61A1CE0]

communications.subject: RE: Indiana Access to Public Records Act Request #2814278
communications.communication:
Potentially responsive records include correspondence of the University with the Office of the Governor about the indicated subjects. These may be identified as documents which indicate the Governor of the State of Indiana as either sender or recipient. Upon information and belief, such correspondence is handled by the Office of the Vice President for University Relations. I do not know how this Office conducts such correspondence, but I assume it is conducted via postal mail, email, or facsimile. 

Potentially responsive records may also include statements of university policy; proposed university policies or resolutions; memorandums; meeting materials such as  invitations, agendas or minutes; opinions of counsel or requests for legal opinions of counsel. Attached documents, such as email messages used to deliver memorandums or executive summaries, should also be considered responsive. Upon information and belief, this material is handled by the Board of Trustees. 

I reiterate that records date from March 4 or later, and mention one or more of the following: "Executive Order 25-35"; "Executive Order 25-36"; "Title IX"; "biological sex", "gender identity"; or "gender ideology." 

TM

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I request the NCAA Membership Financial Reporting System revenue and expense reports for fiscal (or reporting) years 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023 & 2024. Specifically:

These reports are completed by the athletic department for the National Collegiate Athletic Association for the fiscal years listed above. This report is a multi-page document that had to be submitted to the NCAA in January. It contains 40+ revenue and expense categories, followed by specific breakdowns of each of those categories, by sport and gender. I am requesting the full report, including the detail tables, the “Other Reporting Items” list and the “Statement of Revenues and Expenses” that appears at the end of the report. PLEASE NOTE: The NCAA report is different than the equity report that is sent to the U.S. Department of Education for Title IX compliance.

I prefer to receive the records electronically as an Adobe Acrobat (.pdf) file.

If you choose to deny this request, please provide a written explanation for the denial including a reference to the specific statutory exemption(s) on which you rely. Also, please provide all segregable portions of otherwise exempt material.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Stacey Brook.

title: Entry/Exit Overstay Report for the Republic of Ecuador (Department of Homeland Security)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Entry/Exit Overstay Report for the Republic of Ecuador (Department of Homeland Security)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1) Please provide an Entry/Exit Overstay Report for Ecuadorian nonimmigrants admitted to the United States for business or pleasure via air and sea from the Republic of Ecuador. The period of said report shall be from October 1st, 2020 to August 24th, 2021.

Please include in the said report:
- Expected Departures
- Out-of country Overstays
- Suspected In-Country Overstays
- Include age groups and gender

2) Please provide an Entry/Exit Overstay Report for Ecuadorian nonimmigrant students and exchange visitors (F, M, J) admitted to the United States from the Republic of Ecuador. The period of said report shall be from October 1st, 2020 to August 24th, 2021.

Please include in the said report:
- Expected Departures
- Out-of country Overstays
- Suspected In-Country Overstays
- Include age groups and gender

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

communications.subject: NT Acknowledgement Letter
communications.communication:
Cristobal Lamar 
MuckRock News DEPT MR 118151 
411A Highland Ave 
Somerville, MA, 02144-2516 
08/30/2021 
CBP-2021-098543 
Dear Cristobal Lamar: 
This notice acknowledges receipt of your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) received on 08/25/2021 in which you are seeking for,  "Entry/Exit Overstay Report for Ecuadorian non-immigrants, non-immigrant students, and exchange visitors (F, M, J) admitted to the United States for business or pleasure from Ecuador." Date range: October 1st, 2020 to August 24th, 2021. 
Please use the following unique FOIA tracking number CBP-2021-098543 to track the status of your request.  If you have not already done so, you must create a FOIAonline account at https://foiaonline.gov.  This is the only method available to check the status of your pending FOIA request. (https://foiaonline.regulations.gov/) 
Provisions of the Act allow us to recover part of the cost of complying with your request.  We shall charge you for records in accordance with the DHS FOIA regulations outlined on the DHS website, https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2016/11/22/2016-28095/freedom-of-information-act-regulations. By submitting your request, you have agreed to pay up to $25.00 in applicable processing fees, if any fees associated with your request exceed this amount, CBP shall contact you; however, the first 100 pages are free. (https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2016/11/22/2016-28095/freedom-of-information-act-regulations) 
Due to the increasing number of FOIA requests received by this office, we may encounter some delay in processing your request.  Consistent with 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.5(a) of the DHS FOIA regulations, CBP processes FOIA requests according to their order of receipt.  Although CBP’s goal is to respond within 20 business days of receipt of your request, FOIA does permit a 10-day extension of this time period in certain circumstances pursuant to 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.5(c).  [As your request seeks documents that will require a thorough and wide-ranging search, CBP will invoke a 10-day extension for your request pursuant to 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.5(c). If you would like to narrow the scope of your request, please contact our office.  We will make every effort to comply with your request in a timely manner.] OR [As your request seeks a voluminous amount of separate and distinct records, CBP will invoke a 10-day extension for your request pursuant to  6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.5(c).  If you would like to narrow the scope of your request, please contact our office.  We will make every effort to comply with your request in a timely manner.] OR [As the subject matter of your request is of substantial interest to two or more components of CBP or of substantial interest to another agency, we will need to consult with those entities before we issue a final response.  Due to these unusual circumstances, CBP will invoke a 10-day extension for your request pursuant to 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.5(c). If you would like to narrow the scope of your request, please contact our office.  We will make every effort to comply with your request in a timely manner.] 
CBP’s FOIA Division is working hard to reduce the amount of time necessary to respond to FOIA requests.  We truly appreciate your continued patience. 
For additional information please consult CBP FOIA website please click on FOIA Act Resources or visit (http://www.cbp.gov/site-policy-notices/foia) http://www.cbp.gov/site-policy-notices/foia. (http://www.cbp.gov/site-policy-notices/foia) 
Sincerely,

communications.subject: CBP FOIA - CBP-2021-098543
communications.communication:
Cristobal Lamar 
MuckRock News DEPT MR 118151 
411A Highland Ave 
Somerville, Massachusetts 02144-2516 

04/21/2025 

CBP-2021-098543 

Dear Cristobal Lamar: 

This is a final response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) for Entry/Exit Overstay Report for Ecuadorian nonimmigrants admitted to the United States for business or pleasure via air and sea from the Republic of Ecuador. The period of said report shall be from October 1st, 2020 to August 24th, 2021. 

Please include in the said report: 
- Expected Departures 
- Out-of country Overstays 
- Suspected In-Country Overstays 
- Include age groups and gender 

Records are attached to this email. 

CBP is granting your request under the FOIA, Title 5 U.S.C. § 552.  After carefully reviewing the responsive documents, CBP has determined that they are approved for release in their entirety, no deletions or exemptions have been applied. 

For your information, Congress excluded three discrete categories of law enforcement and national security records from the requirements of the FOIA. See 5 U.S.C. 552(c).  This response is limited to those records that are subject to the requirements of the FOIA. This is a standard notification that is given to all our requesters and should not be taken as an indication that excluded records do, or do not, exist. 

You may contact CBP's FOIA Public Liaison, Charlyse Hoskins, by sending an email via your SecureRelease account, mailing a letter to 1300 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW MS 1181, Washington DC, 20229 or by calling 202-325-0150. (If you need telecommunication relay service (TRS) assistance to communicate with the CBP FOIA Office and you are in the United States, please dial 711 to obtain TRS assistance and notify the Communications Assistant that you want to contact the CBP FOIA Office at the telephone number (202) 325-0150). The FOIA Public Liaison is able to assist in advising on the requirements for submitting a request, assist with narrowing the scope of a request, assist in reducing delays by advising the requester on the type of records to request, suggesting agency offices that may have responsive records and receive questions or concerns about the agency’s FOIA process. Please notate file number CBP-2021-098543 on any future correspondence to CBP related to this request. 

Please note that this message has been sent from an unmonitored e-mail account. Any messages sent to this account will not be read. 

Sincerely, 
U.S. Customs and Border Protection

title: Asset Forfeiture Funds (Irvine Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Asset Forfeiture Funds (Irvine Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

- Any accounting records or statistics on seized real estate, vehicles, firearms, funds in bank accounts, and seizures made by the department, as well as seizures made by federal authorities where the department receives a share under the MOUs the department has in place with numerous agencies describing how assets are to be divided.

- Records and data that outlines what was purchased using money from the fund, including dates, descriptions, and total spent. 

- Any annual reports produced civil asset forfeiture program.

- Documents showing the balance of any funds currently in the department Civil Asset Forfeiture fund.

-A list of all items seized through civil asset forfeiture and retained for use by the department

- Sales of non-monetary assets, receipts of sale for vehicles, or the destruction of other non-monetary assets

-Please also include any information relating to contested seizures. This request does not include court documents for individual forfeiture cases.
 
The period for this request is for the last 10 years.

Preferably released in .CSV form when possible

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: Asset Forfeiture Funds (Irvine Police Department) / City's Follow-Up Response
communications.communication:
Good Afternoon Mr. Scott,

As you know, our office is the City Attorney for the City of Irvine and Irvine Police Department (collectively, the “City”).  Please allow this correspondence to serve as the City’s follow-up correspondence to your public records act (“PRA”) request below.

Specifically, the City has reviewed your PRA request and has determined it seeks an excessively large volume of potentially responsive documents spanning a 10-year period, which at this time, would pose a significant undue burden on limited staff time and resources.

In an effort to streamline the documents you seek, the City is requesting further clarification pertaining to the categories of records requested below:

- Any accounting records or statistics on seized real estate, vehicles, firearms, funds in bank accounts, and seizures made by the department, as well as seizures made by federal authorities where the department receives a share under the MOUs the department has in place with numerous agencies describing how assets are to be divided. Please clarify whether you seek information on all seized items, or whether this is specifically requesting information on seizures relating to asset forfeiture.  As phrased, the request is ambiguous and overbroad.  The City requests that you further clarify and/or narrow the scope of this request.

- Sales of non-monetary assets, receipts of sale for vehicles, or the destruction of other non-monetary assets. Please clarify whether this category is specific to asset forfeitures.  As phrased, it is ambiguous and overbroad.  The City requests that you further clarify and/or narrow the scope of this request.

-Please also include any information relating to contested seizures. This request does not include court documents for individual forfeiture cases.  This request as phrased—“any information”—is incredibly overbroad.  Please identify which types of documents and/or specific categories of records you seek.  The City requests that you further clarify and/or narrow the scope of this request.

Finally, as your request spans a 10-year period, please understand the City will need additional time to locate potentially responsive records to this request.  If you could further narrow the time-period requested, it would expedite the processing of these documents for disclosure.

Thank you in advance for your prompt attention to this matter.  We look forward to your response.

Best,

Kelsey

Kelsey Quist<http://www.rutan.com/Kelsey-Quist>
18575 Jamboree Road, 9th Floor | Irvine, CA 92612
O. (714) 641-5100 | D. (714) 338-1864
kquist@rutan.com<mailto:kquist@rutan.com> | www.rutan.com<http://www.rutan.com/>
[cid:image002.png@01DB7E2F.03F28630]<https://www.rutan.com/>
_____________________________________________________
Privileged And Confidential Communication.
This electronic transmission, and any documents attached hereto, (a) are protected by the Electronic Communications Privacy Act (18 USC §§ 2510-2521), (b) may contain confidential and/or legally privileged information, and (c) are for the sole use of the intended recipient named above. If you have received this electronic message in error, please notify the sender and delete the electronic message. Any disclosure, copying, distribution, or use of the contents of the information received in error is strictly prohibited.

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: Asset Forfeiture Funds (Irvine Police Department)
communications.communication:
Hello, 

All of the requested records below are for the department's use of their asset forfeiture fund. I've simplified it for you below. 

- Any accounting records or statistics on seized real estate, vehicles, firearms, funds in bank accounts, and seizures made by the department, as well as seizures made by federal authorities where the department receives a share under the MOUs the department has in place with numerous agencies describing how assets are to be divided. Please clarify whether you seek information on all seized items, or whether this is specifically requesting information on seizures relating to asset forfeiture. As phrased, the request is ambiguous and overbroad. The City requests that you further clarify and/or narrow the scope of this request.

Any ledgers, databases, invoices, receipts, and documentation tracking the acquisition, sales, destruction, or donations of seized real estate, vehicles, firearms, or funds in bank accounts should be included. Information related to the date, quantity, cost, invoices, item description, what was bought, what was sold, and what was donated should also be included. 

-Please also include any information relating to contested seizures. This request does not include court documents for individual forfeiture cases. This request as phrased—“any information”—is incredibly overbroad. Please identify which types of documents and/or specific categories of records you seek. The City requests that you further clarify and/or narrow the scope of this request.

Documentation, databases, memos, or other forms that documents that track cases of contested seizures involving the department. 


Asset forfeiture funds are tightly tracked and documented (or should be) and should be easily accessible for release. Departments were able to provide me with 10 years of records in a humane, uncumbersome manner. 

Thank you!

Good Afternoon Mr. Scott,

Thank you for your patience as the City has now finished processing all records responsive to your PRA request.  The responsive records can be uploaded from the secure access link below:


You are being provided access to documents by Rutan & Tucker, LLP.

Click here to download your file(s)<https://rutantucker.thruinc.net/Desktop/Distro/Open/031RL2N8SQ9> - Expires Monday 19 May 2025 06:59 AM (UTC)


Or, copy this link to a browser: https://rutantucker.thruinc.net/Desktop/Distro/Open/031RL2N8SQ9


Please be advised certain redactions were made to the PDF document entitled “State Asset Forfeiture Log” to protect discussions concerning open/ongoing criminal investigations, pursuant to Gov. Code § 7923.600(a).

With service of the records produced in the link above, the City will now close this PRA.  Should you have any questions, please feel free to contact out office.

Best,

Kelsey

Kelsey Quist<http://www.rutan.com/Kelsey-Quist>
18575 Jamboree Road, 9th Floor | Irvine, CA 92612
